trans-unit.source: Manage scenes
trans-unit.target: Manage scenes

trans-unit.source: Beginner Programmer Designer
trans-unit.target: Beginner Programmer Designer

trans-unit.source: Scenes and entities are arranged in a hierarchy, with the root scene at the top. This hierarchy is displayed in the Entity Tree in the Scene Editor on the left.
trans-unit.target: Scenes and entities are arranged in a hierarchy, with the root scene at the top. This hierarchy is displayed in the Entity Tree in the Scene Editor on the left.

trans-unit.source: Scene hierarchy tree
trans-unit.target: Scene hierarchy tree

trans-unit.source: The root scene contains all the scenes and entities in your game. It should contain common entities that the other scenes and entities use, such as game logic scripts.
trans-unit.target: The root scene contains all the scenes and entities in your game. It should contain common entities that the other scenes and entities use, such as game logic scripts.

trans-unit.source: Scene hierarchy diagram
trans-unit.target: Scene hierarchy diagram

trans-unit.source: Scenes are kept in different folders. This means that different people can work on them without overwriting each other's work.
trans-unit.target: Scenes are kept in different folders. This means that different people can work on them without overwriting each other's work.

trans-unit.source: !Note When scenes load at runtime, their child scenes aren't automatically loaded too. You have to load child scenes in code. For more information, see Load scenes.
trans-unit.target: !Note When scenes load at runtime, their child scenes aren't automatically loaded too. You have to load child scenes in code. For more information, see Load scenes.

trans-unit.source: Set parent and child scenes
trans-unit.target: Set parent and child scenes

trans-unit.source: The relationship between parent and child scenes is set on the child, not the parent. In other words, child scenes know about their parent scenes, but parent scenes don't know about their child scenes.
trans-unit.target: The relationship between parent and child scenes is set on the child, not the parent. In other words, child scenes know about their parent scenes, but parent scenes don't know about their child scenes.

trans-unit.source: There are several ways to make a scene a child of another scene:
trans-unit.target: There are several ways to make a scene a child of another scene:

trans-unit.source: In the Scene Editor Entity Tree (left by default), drag the scene onto the scene you want to make its parent.
trans-unit.target: In the Scene Editor Entity Tree (left by default), drag the scene onto the scene you want to make its parent.

trans-unit.source: Drag the scene from the Asset View (bottom by default) onto the scene you want to make its parent in the Entity Tree.
trans-unit.target: Drag the scene from the Asset View (bottom by default) onto the scene you want to make its parent in the Entity Tree.

trans-unit.source: In the scene Property Grid (on the right by default), next to Parent, specify the scene you want to be the scene's parent.
trans-unit.target: In the scene Property Grid (on the right by default), next to Parent, specify the scene you want to be the scene's parent.

trans-unit.source: Properties parent scene
trans-unit.target: Properties parent scene

trans-unit.source: Set the default scene
trans-unit.target: Set the default scene

trans-unit.source: The default scene is the scene Stride loads at runtime. You can set this in the Game Settings asset.
trans-unit.target: The default scene is the scene Stride loads at runtime. You can set this in the Game Settings asset.

trans-unit.source: In the Solution Explorer (the bottom-left pane by default), select the Assets folder.
trans-unit.target: In the Solution Explorer (the bottom-left pane by default), select the Assets folder.

trans-unit.source: Select Assets folder asset
trans-unit.target: Select Assets folder asset

trans-unit.source: In the Asset View (the bottom pane by default), select the GameSettings asset.
trans-unit.target: In the Asset View (the bottom pane by default), select the GameSettings asset.

trans-unit.source: Select Game Settings asset
trans-unit.target: Select Game Settings asset

trans-unit.source: In the Property Grid (the right-hand pane by default), next to Default Scene, click Hand icon (Select an asset).
trans-unit.target: In the Property Grid (the right-hand pane by default), next to Default Scene, click Hand icon (Select an asset).

trans-unit.source: Set default scene
trans-unit.target: Set default scene

trans-unit.source: The Select an asset window opens.
trans-unit.target: The Select an asset window opens.

trans-unit.source: Select the default scene and click OK.
trans-unit.target: Select the default scene and click OK.

trans-unit.source: Stride loads this scene at runtime.
trans-unit.target: Stride loads this scene at runtime.

trans-unit.source: For more information about the Game Settings asset, see Game Settings.
trans-unit.target: For more information about the Game Settings asset, see Game Settings.

trans-unit.source: Set the active scene
trans-unit.target: Set the active scene

trans-unit.source: The active scene is the scene entities are added to when you drop them in the Scene Editor. Game Studio adds the entities as children to the active scene.
trans-unit.target: The active scene is the scene entities are added to when you drop them in the Scene Editor. Game Studio adds the entities as children to the active scene.

trans-unit.source: To set the active scene, Entity Tree (left by default), right-click the scene and select active scene.
trans-unit.target: To set the active scene, Entity Tree (left by default), right-click the scene and select active scene.

trans-unit.source: Set active scene
trans-unit.target: Set active scene

trans-unit.source: The active scene has no effect on runtime.
trans-unit.target: The active scene has no effect on runtime.

trans-unit.source: Lock scenes and entities
trans-unit.target: Lock scenes and entities

trans-unit.source: You can lock scenes and entities so they can't be selected in the main window. This is useful when you have lots of things in your scene. You can still select scenes and entities in the Entity Tree.
trans-unit.target: You can lock scenes and entities so they can't be selected in the main window. This is useful when you have lots of things in your scene. You can still select scenes and entities in the Entity Tree.

trans-unit.source: To lock or unlock a scene or entity, in the Entity Tree, click the padlock icon.
trans-unit.target: To lock or unlock a scene or entity, in the Entity Tree, click the padlock icon.

trans-unit.source: Padlock icon
trans-unit.target: Padlock icon

trans-unit.source: !Tip When you lock a scene, all its child scenes and entities are locked too. To lock an entity along with its child entities, hold Ctrl and click the padlock icon.
trans-unit.target: !Tip When you lock a scene, all its child scenes and entities are locked too. To lock an entity along with its child entities, hold Ctrl and click the padlock icon.

trans-unit.source: Locked items have a gold locked padlock icon in the Entity Tree.
trans-unit.target: Locked items have a gold locked padlock icon in the Entity Tree.

trans-unit.source: Locked entity
trans-unit.target: Locked entity

trans-unit.source: Load and unload scenes in the Scene Editor
trans-unit.target: Load and unload scenes in the Scene Editor

trans-unit.source: You can load and unload scenes (with all their child scenes and entities) in the Scene Editor. Unloading scenes in the editor is useful if, for example, you want to remove clutter from your editing view, or improve editor performance.
trans-unit.target: You can load and unload scenes (with all their child scenes and entities) in the Scene Editor. Unloading scenes in the editor is useful if, for example, you want to remove clutter from your editing view, or improve editor performance.

trans-unit.source: The screenshots below show a root scene with child scenes loaded and unloaded. The root scene contains entities that all the scenes use, including the skybox, scripts, asteroids, and player character. The child scenes are sections of level.
trans-unit.target: The screenshots below show a root scene with child scenes loaded and unloaded. The root scene contains entities that all the scenes use, including the skybox, scripts, asteroids, and player character. The child scenes are sections of level.

trans-unit.source: Unloaded and loaded scenes
trans-unit.target: Unloaded and loaded scenes

trans-unit.source: To load or unload a scene, in the Scene Editor, in the Entity Tree on the left, next to the scene you want to load or unload, click the eye icon.
trans-unit.target: To load or unload a scene, in the Scene Editor, in the Entity Tree on the left, next to the scene you want to load or unload, click the eye icon.

trans-unit.source: Load scene icon
trans-unit.target: Load scene icon

trans-unit.source: Move a scene
trans-unit.target: Move a scene

trans-unit.source: As scenes aren't entities, they don't have transform components. However, you can move a scene using its offset property.
trans-unit.target: As scenes aren't entities, they don't have transform components. However, you can move a scene using its offset property.

trans-unit.source: Scene offset property
trans-unit.target: Scene offset property

trans-unit.source: To move a scene at runtime, use:
trans-unit.target: To move a scene at runtime, use:

trans-unit.source: Replace myScene with the name of the scene, and x,y,z with the XYZ coordinates you want to move the scene to.
trans-unit.target: Replace myScene with the name of the scene, and x,y,z with the XYZ coordinates you want to move the scene to.

trans-unit.source: See also
trans-unit.target: See also
